results.title: Valley of the Yarra
results.creator_credit: Peter McEwan, Donald Pollock, Matthias Faubel and Victorian Town and Country Planning Board
results.brief_description: Using archival stills and prints, and aerial shots the film traces the Yarra River from its source in the Great Dividing Range to its entry into Port Phillip Bay, emphasising its importance as a natural asset. Also shows geographical features such as the delta from Princes Bridge, Melbourne to Fisherman’s Bend, the port complex and various sporting facilities. Discusses the planning policy for the Yarra Valley prepared by the Town and Country Planning Board, Victoria’s state planning authority. “Modern man causes problems to this priceless asset” (Liberal Minister Dick Hamer).
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter McEwan, Donald Pollock, Matthias Faubel and Victorian Town and Country Planning Board

results.title: Headstart for Omar
results.creator_credit: Myrtle Winter-Chaumeny, United Nations Television and United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East
results.brief_description: Omar was a boy when he fled with his parents from the family orange grove near Jaffa and joined 750,000 Palastinian Arab refugees streaming out of the new State of Israel. Ever since then Omar has waited and now lives in Qatar, where he works and bides his time. Like others of 1948, Omar waits for the world community to settle a long overdue account.

results.title: Think back: an introduction to safe and efficient patient transfer and object handling
results.creator_credit: Phil Fury, Geoff Crane and Australia. Repatriation Dept.
results.brief_description:
This 1975 film, commissioned by the Australian Repatriation Department, provides instruction on the correct methods of manual handling in order to avoid back injury. The film contains three distinct sections: the first focusing on the principles for lifting heavy objects; the second showing different methods for lifting patients in the hospital; and the third showing methods for manoeuvring heavy loads such as shovelling material and pushing a trolley.

The first section includes animated sections showing the anatomy of the spine and the different types of back injury, including slipped disks, muscle and ligament strain. It then outlines the steps for lifting a heavy load, focusing on a truck driver loading various objects onto the tray of his vehicle.

The second section is directed at hospital staff, as an instructional video for lifting patients correctly. It shows methods of lifting patients up in bed, into a wheelchair and into a bath. Of particular note is the athletic wear (leotards and tracksuits) of the period worn by the nurses and patients in the demonstrations.

The third section shows methods of manual handling in everyday life with correct posture and stability, including shovelling material; pushing a trolley; and lifting a box into the back seat of a car.

A Repatriation Commission Film
Consultant: David Ferguson, Associate Professor in occupational health, the University of Sydney

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Get out and live
results.creator_credit: Col Lewis and Cameracraft Film Productions
results.brief_description:
This 1972 film, produced for the Main Roads Department, Brisbane, describes the establishment of an emergency control organisation within the department, and shows the training and implementation of an emergency evacuation of 1,500 people from the 14 storey office building.

Produced by Cameracraft Film Productions.

The colour is faded throughout the film and there are jumps in the soundtrack throughout due to missing frames.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Don't lose your grip
results.creator_credit: Joan Hansen, R.D. Hansen, Fortune Film Productions and New South Wales. Dept. of Labour and Industry
results.brief_description:
This 1961 film illustrates safe methods for handling and storage of rolled steel joists, angles and plates in steel yards. Accompanied by an instructional narration, the film opens with a dramatised scene of an injured man caught beneath a steel beam due to the carelessness of a workmate. It shows footage of correct methods of stacking and storing steel beams, angles and plates, as well as demonstrating correct use of lifting equipment.

Produced by Fortune Film Productions and the New South Wales Department of Labour and Industry.

There are several jumps in the soundtrack throughout the film due to missing frames.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: [Remix: The Races]
results.creator_credit: Dakota Henderson, ACMI Collections and ACMI
results.brief_description:
This short remix of films about horse racing set to music, takes you through from getting ready and arriving at the track, to placing a bet, the race and the result.

This playful short film set to music, is a tribute to some of the activities around the spring racing carnival that takes place in Melbourne during October and November. It captures the race preparations for both people and horses, and shows the mounting yard, the TAB bets, the race call and a punter finding out the winner.

ACMI gratefully acknowledge donor: Ivan Gaal ( Dir., ‘The Punter’, 1978).

results.title: About my dad
results.creator_credit: Huong Duy Pham, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Like his father, Huong Duy Pham was also a soldier in the South Vietnam Army. But his family connections were to prove too dangerous and Huong eventually escaped by boat and made his way to Australia where he is now living with his wife and three sons. He dedicates this story to his father.

results.title: [Remix: ACMI Collection 2]
results.brief_description:
This playful short film set to music, is a tribute to the gems in the ACMI Collection. A remix of home movies and short works from the collection featuring elements on ‘how a movie is made’ and a split screen collage of moving images, interspersed with intertitles. The work was initially designed as part of a fundraising campaign.

ACMI gratefully acknowledge the following donors and creators in the compilation of this work: Australian Dried Fruits Association; John Richardson; Tasmanian Archive and Heritage Office; Ivan Gaal; Wine Australia and Tony Agapitos.

results.title: [Remix: Strike A Pose]
results.creator_credit: Sam Mapplebeck, ACMI Collections and ACMI
results.brief_description:
This playful short film set to music, is a tribute to people posing for the camera. A remix of home movies and short works in the ACMI Collection featuring families, fashion models and even a dog, all striking a pose for the camera. On a fashion catwalk, in a parade, on a photoshoot, in a factory or outdoor setting or just the back yard, fashionistas and family folk put their best foot forward from the 1940s to 1970s.

ACMI gratefully acknowledge the following donors and creators in the compilation of this work: Dried Fruits Australia, Karen Wootton, Elenor Peach, Tasmanian Archive and Heritage Office, Jenny & Owen Peake, Tony Agapitos and Ivan Gaal.

results.title: Timber sense
results.creator_credit: Tasmania Dept. of Labour and Industry and Tasmania. Dept. of Film Production
results.brief_description:
This 1961 film shows some of the ways in which accidents may be prevented in the timber production industry, in forests and sawmills. While working in the forest, the film shows the importance of wearing safety helmets and boots to avoid the danger of falling limbs; creating a clear getaway from felled trunks; and safely loading logs onto a timber truck. It then shows safe practices when working in sawmills, including wearing safety glasses to protect against sawdust and splinters; installing guards on circular saws; and keeping the floor clear.

Produced by the Tasmania Department of Film Production for the Department of Labour and Industry.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.
